content.text: OWASP Top 10 is a standard awareness document representing the most critical security risks to web applications worldwide. It is compiled by the Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) and updated regularly based on real-world vulnerability data.

The OWASP Top 10 provides a focused list of the most common and dangerous security vulnerabilities found in web applications. Understanding and addressing these risks is essential for building secure applications. VaultGuard Pro specifically scans for these vulnerabilities to help protect your website.

content.title: A01: Broken Access Control
content.text: Users can access resources or perform actions outside of their intended permissions. This is the most common vulnerability, allowing unauthorized access to sensitive data or administrative functions.

items: Example: Regular users accessing admin panels
Example: Viewing other users' private data by changing URL parameters

content.title: A02: Cryptographic Failures
content.text: Sensitive data is not properly encrypted or uses weak encryption. Previously called 'Sensitive Data Exposure', this risk focuses on failures related to cryptography.

items: Example: Storing passwords in plain text
Example: Using outdated encryption algorithms (MD5, SHA1)
Example: Transmitting sensitive data over unencrypted connections

content.title: A03: Injection
content.text: Untrusted data is sent to an interpreter as part of a command or query, allowing attackers to execute malicious code. This includes SQL, NoSQL, OS command, and LDAP injection.

items: Example: SQL Injection - manipulating database queries
Example: Command Injection - executing system commands
Example: NoSQL Injection - exploiting NoSQL databases
Example: LDAP Injection - manipulating LDAP queries

content.title: A04: Insecure Design
content.text: Security flaws in the design phase of applications. This is a new category focusing on risks related to design and architectural flaws, rather than implementation issues.

items: Example: Missing rate limiting on authentication
Example: Weak authentication mechanisms designed from the start
Example: Lack of security controls in the design

content.title: A05: Security Misconfiguration
content.text: Incorrect security settings in default configurations, incomplete configurations, open cloud storage, misconfigured HTTP headers, and verbose error messages.

items: Example: Verbose error messages exposing system details

content.title: A06: Vulnerable and Outdated Components
content.text: Using components (libraries, frameworks, plugins) with known vulnerabilities. This includes both client-side and server-side components.

items: Example: Outdated WordPress plugins with known CVEs
Example: Old JavaScript libraries with security flaws

content.title: A07: Identification and Authentication Failures
content.text: Weak authentication mechanisms, session management flaws, and identity verification issues. Previously called 'Broken Authentication'.

content.title: A08: Software and Data Integrity Failures
content.text: Unverified software updates, untrusted sources, and CI/CD pipeline vulnerabilities. Previously called 'Insecure Deserialization'.

items: Example: Accepting code from untrusted sources without verification
Example: Insecure deserialization of untrusted data

content.title: A09: Security Logging and Monitoring Failures
content.text: Insufficient logging and monitoring, missing security event logs, and inability to detect security incidents. Previously called 'Insufficient Logging & Monitoring'.

content.title: A10: Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
content.text: Forcing the server to make requests to unintended locations, often internal systems that should not be accessible from the internet.

items: Example: Using your server to attack internal systems
